## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (Lucy, OSIRIS-APEX, Mars)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2024-01-14T19:33:58Z
## Message ID: 20240114-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

C-type CME detected by SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2024-01-14T12:00Z.

Estimated speed: ~948 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 37 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 105/-23 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2024-01-14T12:00:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact Lucy (minor impact), OSIRIS-APEX, and Mars (glancing blow). The leading edge of the CME will reach Lucy at 2024-01-20T08:00Z and OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-01-15T15:37Z (plus minus 7 hours), and the flank of the CME will reach Mars at 2024-01-18T07:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME: 2024-01-14T12:00:00-CME-001):

(a) 2 AU outer boundary
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20240114_155200_2.0_anim.tim-den.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20240114_155200_2.0_anim.tim-vel.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20240114_155200_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20240114_155200_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_Mars_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20240114_155200_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_Osiris_timeline.gif

(b) 5.5 AU outer boundary
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20240114_155200_5.5_anim.tim-den.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20240114_155200_5.5_anim.tim-vel.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20240114_155200_5.5_ENLIL_CONE_Lucy_timeline.gif


## Notes: 

This CME event (2024-01-14T12:00:00-CME-001) is associated with C9.6 flare (N01W90) with ID 2024-01-14T11:30:00-FLR-001 which peaked at 2024-01-14T12:06Z.


SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for January 03, 2024 - January 09, 2024
##
## Message Issue Date: 2024-01-10T20:59:38Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2024-01-03T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2024-01-09T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20240110-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at minor to moderate levels during this reporting period with 2 M-class flares and 9 C-type CMEs (see details below).   

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the C-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery at 2024-01-09T15:48Z may give a glancing blow at NASA missions near Earth at about 2024-01-12T09:00Z (plus minus 7 hours) with a maximum estimated Kp index of 3-4 (below minor) (see notification 20240110-AL-002).

It was also estimated that the following CMEs are predicted to impact the following locations:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
----------------------------------------------------------------------------- 
2024-01-04T00:00Z Mars at 2024-01-09T00:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240104-AL-001 ) 
2024-01-05T01:53Z Solar Orbiter at 2024-01-07T20:00Z (glancing blow) 
2024-01-06T08:12Z STEREO A at 2024-01-09T02:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240106-AL-001)
2024-01-06T08:12Z Solar Orbiter at 2024-01-09T08:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240106-AL-001)
2024-01-06T08:12Z Psyche at 2024-01-10T08:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240106-AL-001 )
2024-01-08T13:25Z Solar Orbiter at 2024-01-11T20:00Z (minor impact)
2024-01-09T06:48Z OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-01-10T21:33Z (see notification 20240110-AL-001)
2024-01-09T15:48Z Solar Orbiter at 2024-01-12T11:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240110-AL-002)
2024-01-09T15:48Z STEREO A at 2024-01-12T12:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240110-AL-002)
2024-01-09T15:48Z Psyche at 2024-01-13T12:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240110-AL-002)

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3.00 for the reporting period.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The gradual solar energetic particle event detected by SOHO at the end of the previous reporting period (see notification 20240103-AL-001) continued through the beginning of the reporting period. The solar energetic particle event was also detected by GOES at 2024-01-03T20:05Z, when the already elevated flux of > 10 MeV protons exceeded the threshold of 10 pfu (see notifications 20240103-AL-003 and 20240103-AL-004). This solar energetic particle event was associated with the heightened activity from Active Region 13536: mainly the X5.0 flare close to the East limb in the previous reporting period (see notifications 20231231-AL-002 and 20231231-AL-003) and the associated R-type CME (see notification 20240101-AL-001), with possible additional contributions from the subsequent lower M-class flares from Active Region 13536. The energetic flux of 13-100 MeV protons detected at STEREO A was significantly elevated but remained below the threshold of 10^(-1) pfu/MeV. The proton fluxes at SOHO and GOES subsided to below their respective threshold levels on 2024-01-05. The energetic particle fluxes at all three locations have since decreased to background levels.  

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been moderate to high this week due to the solar energetic particle events at SOHO and GOES described above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2024-01-10T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date: 2024-01-16T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between low and moderate levels during the outlook period. Currently, there are ten numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. Active Region 13536 (N07W56) produced two M-class flares early in the reporting period as well as multiple C-class flares throughout it and will possibly generate some activity before it rotates off the Earth-facing disk on or around 2024-01-13. Active Region 13538 (N20W77) has been the source of C-class flaring but will soon be rotating behind the limb. Finally, a lower M-class flare was produced today by a yet unnumbered Active Region right on the Eastern limb (at around S20 latitude). This Active Region may exhibit flaring activity throughout the outlook period.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. An increase in geomagnetic activity might be observed  at the beginning of the outlook period due to a possible glancing blow from the S-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery at 2024-01-06T17:36Z. Further increase in geomagnetic activity might happen on or around 2024-01-12 due to a possible glancing blow from the C-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery at 2024-01-09T15:48Z mentioned above, possibly combined with an influence from the diffuse southern coronal hole which crossed the central meridian on 2024-01-09, as seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO AIA, and might become geoeffective on or around 2024-01-13.

## Summary:

C-type CME detected by SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2024-01-09T15:48Z.

Estimated speed: ~674 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 41 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -26/-36 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2024-01-09T15:48:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that this CME may affect Psyche (glancing blow), Solar Orbiter (glancing blow), and STEREO A (glancing blow).  The flank of the CME may reach Psyche at 2024-01-13T12:00Z, Solar Orbiter at 2024-01-12T11:00Z, and STEREO A at 2024-01-12T12:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The simulation also indicates that the CME may have a glancing blow at NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the flank of the CME may reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2024-01-12T09:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 3-4 (below minor).

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for December 27, 2023 - January 02, 2024
##
## Message Issue Date: 2024-01-03T23:26:36Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2023-12-27T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2024-01-02T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20240103-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at high levels during this reporting period with 1 X-class flare and 4 M-class flares (see list below). There were 13 C-type CMEs and 1 R-type CME (see details below).

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the R-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery at 2023-12-31T22:00Z may give a glancing blow to NASA missions near Earth at about 2024-01-02T18:00Z (plus minus 7 hours) with a maximum estimated Kp index of 3-5 (below minor to minor) (see notification 20240101-AL-001). The arrival of this CME was possibly detected by DSCOVR at L1 at 2024-01-03T04:50Z (see notification 20240103-AL-002). Analysis of this arrival signature is ongoing. 

It was also estimated that the following CMEs are predicted to impact the following locations:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2023-12-27T01:48Z OSIRIS-APEX at 2023-12-28T18:31Z (see notification 20231227-AL-001).
2023-12-27T04:00Z Mars at 2023-12-31T19:00Z (glancing blow).
2023-12-31T10:00Z OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-01-01T23:31Z (see notification 20231231-AL-001).
2023-12-31T22:00Z Solar Orbiter at 2024-01-02T07:00Z, Juno at 2024-01-11T00:18Z, Psyche at 2024-01-03T12:30Z (glancing blow), STEREO A at 2024-01-02T23:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240101-AL-001).
2024-01-02T11:09Z OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-01-04T06:00Z (glancing blow), Mars at 2024-01-07T03:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240102-AL-001).

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4.00 for the reporting period.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

During the reporting period, there was a solar energetic particle event detected by SOHO. At SOHO, the flux of one or more of the >15.8 MeV protons channels exceeded 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2024-01-02T23:22Z (see notification 20240103-AL-001). This solar energetic particle event may be associated with an X5.0 flare from AR 13536 (N04E80) which peaked at 2023-12-31T21:55Z (see notifications 20231231-AL-002 and 20231231-AL-003) along with an associated R-type CME first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2023-12-31T22:00Z (see notification 20240101-AL-001). The observed elevation in one or more of the >15.8 MeV proton channels was gradual and continued to oscillate around the 10^(-1) pfu/MeV threshold through the end of the reporting period. Analysis of this SEP event and all possibly associated activity is ongoing. The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons detected at STEREO A were elevated above background levels during the latter part of the reporting period but did not exceed their respective thresholds of 10 pfu and 10^(-1) pfu/MeV before the end of the reporting period.

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been moderate to high this week due to the solar energetic particle event detected at SOHO.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2024-01-03T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2024-01-09T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between minor and moderate levels during the outlook period. Currently, there are four numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. Active Region 13536 (N05E37) was responsible for the notable X-class and M-class flares observed during the reporting period and this region may continue to exhibit additional flaring activity as it transits the Earth-facing disk during the outlook period.
 
Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. A coronal hole structure centered near S30E28 (as seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO AIA) could become geoeffective during the latter part of the outlook period on or around 2023-01-07. Recently, the flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES exceeded the threshold of 10 pfu starting at 2024-01-03T20:05Z (see notifications 20240103-AL-003 and 20240103-AL-004). The >10 MeV integral proton flux at GOES is currently sustained above or near the 10 pfu threshold and this elevation may persist throughout the beginning part of the outlook period.

## Summary:

Solar activity was at minor to moderate levels during this reporting period with 5 M-class flares and 9 C-type CMEs (see details below).

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the C-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery at 2023-12-24T13:25Z may give a glancing blow to NASA missions near Earth at about 2023-12-28T01:00Z (plus minus 7 hours) with a maximum estimated Kp index of 3-4 (below minor) (see notification 20231224-AL-001).

It was also estimated that the following CMEs are predicted to impact the following locations:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2023-12-21T06:09Z    OSIRIS-APEX at 2023-12-22T15:36Z (see notification 20231221-AL-003).
2023-12-22T00:24Z    OSIRIS-APEX at 2023-12-23T19:07Z (see notification 20231222-AL-001).
2023-12-22T01:25Z    OSIRIS-APEX at 2023-12-23T19:07Z (see notification 20231222-AL-001). 
2023-12-22T05:12Z    OSIRIS-APEX at 2023-12-23T19:07Z (see notification 20231222-AL-001).
2023-12-24T13:25Z    Solar Orbiter at 2023-12-27T13:00Z (glancing blow) and STEREO A at 2023-12-28T02:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20231224-AL-001).
2023-12-26T00:12Z    OSIRIS-APEX at 2023-12-27T18:07Z (see notification 20231226-AL-001).

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp<=4 occurred during the synoptic period of 2023-12-20T00:00Z-03:00Z. This slight enhancement in geomagnetic activity was associated with the possible arrival of the S-type CME first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2023-12-16T01:48Z detected at L1 by DSCOVR and ACE at 2023-12-20T00:26Z.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold of 1000 pfu at 2023-12-21T13:35Z (see notifications 20231221-AL-001, 20231221-AL-002, and 20231223-AL-001) and remained elevated until returning to background levels early on 2023-12-24. These elevated energetic electron flux levels are likely associated with the combined arrivals of the CME first seen at 2023-12-14T17:38Z detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 around 2023-12-17T07:32Z (see notification 20231221-7D-001), a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2023-12-18, and the CME first seen at 2023-12-16T01:48Z detected at L1 by DSCOVR and ACE at 2023-12-20T00:26Z mentioned above.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A remained near or slightly above background levels for the entire reporting period. The slight elevation seen at GOES may be associated to recent M-class flaring activity and CMEs departing the Sun from on and/or beyond the western side of the Earth-facing disk. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2023-12-27T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2024-01-02T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between minor and moderate levels for the outlook period. There are currently five Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. The most notable of these, Active Region 13529 (S21W62), produced two of the M-class flares during the reporting period and may continue to exhibit similar levels of activity during the outlook period. 

Geomagnetic activity is expected to be minor for the upcoming week. A large coronal hole currently centered near S15E25 (stretching from N10E10 to S30E50) will begin to cross the central meridian by the end of 2023-12-28. The western most portions of this coronal hole may reach geoeffective longitudes by the end of the outlook period. We are still awaiting the potential glancing blow of the C-type CME first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2023-12-24T13:25Z where minor geomagnetic conditions are possible.

## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for December 13, 2023 - December 19, 2023
##
## Message Issue Date: 2023-12-21T00:55:45Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2023-12-13T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2023-12-19T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20231221-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at high levels during this reporting period with 1 X-class flare, 5 M-class flares, 7 C-type CMEs, and 2 O-type CMEs (see details below).   

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the C-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery at 2023-12-13T00:00Z associated with a C2.8 flare from AR 13514 (N06W25) peaking at 2023-12-12T22:55Z may impact NASA missions near Earth at about 2023-12-15T15:13Z (plus minus 7 hours) with a maximum estimated Kp index of 3-5 (below minor to minor) (see notification 20231213-AL-002). The arrival of this CME was likely detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 at 2023-12-15T10:57Z (see notification 20231215-AL-006). STEREO A IMPACT and PLASTIC instruments have also likely detected the arrival of this CME around 2023-12-15T12:41Z. 

Additionally, it was estimated that the O-type CME first visible in STEREO A COR2 imagery at 2023-12-14T17:38Z associated with an X2.8 flare from AR 13514 (N05W54) peaking at 2023-12-14T17:02Z (see notifications 20231214-AL-005, 20231214-AL-006) may impact NASA missions near Earth at about 2023-12-16T18:51Z (plus minus 7 hours) with a maximum estimated Kp index of 5-7 (minor to strong) (see notifications 20231214-AL-007, 20231215-AL-001, and 20231216-AL-002). An ensemble simulation was performed for this CME with 24 members which estimated the CME to reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2023-12-16T15:53Z and 2023-12-17T09:58Z (average arrival 2023-12-16T22:15Z) for 75% of simulations. The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 79% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 3-6 range (below minor to moderate). Full details of the modeled event are available here:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-12-16_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA055/Detailed_results_20231214_173800_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA055.txt (see notification 20231216-AL-002). The arrival of this CME was likely detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 at 2023-12-17T07:32Z (see notification 20231217-AL-002). STEREO A IMPACT and PLASTIC instruments also likely detected the arrival of this CME around 2023-12-17T00:30Z.

It was also estimated that the following CMEs are predicted to impact the following locations:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2023-12-13T00:00Z   OSIRIS-APEX at 2023-12-14T09:08Z, Psyche at 2023-12-16T07:15Z, Solar Orbiter at 2023-12-15T15:06Z, STEREO A at 2023-12-15T13:13Z (see notification 20231213-AL-002)
2023-12-13T15:05Z   OSIRIS-APEX at 2023-12-15T09:47Z (see notification 20231215-AL-001)
2023-12-14T07:00Z   OSIRIS-APEX at 2023-12-15T18:00Z (see notification 20231215-AL-001)
2023-12-14T08:36Z   OSIRIS-APEX at 2023-12-15T18:00Z (see notifications 20231215-AL-001)
2023-12-14T17:38Z   OSIRIS-APEX at 2023-12-15T18:00Z, Psyche at 2023-12-17T08:42Z, Solar Orbiter at 2023-12-16T23:48Z, STEREO A = 2023-12-16T16:59Z (see notifications 20231215-AL-001 and 20231216-AL-002).
2023-12-15T07:48Z   OSIRIS-APEX at 2023-12-16T10:44Z, STEREO A at 2023-12-18T07:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20231215-AL-009)
2023-12-17T18:36Z   Lucy = 2023-12-23T00:00Z (minor impact)

Geomagnetic activity was at moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=6 for the reporting period (see notifications 20231218-AL-001 and 20231218-AL-002). The highest value of Kp=6 occurred during the synoptic period 2023-12-18T06:00Z-09:00Z. This moderate geomagnetic activity was associated with the interplanetary shock detected at L1 by DSCOVR and ACE at 2023-12-17T07:32Z (see notification 20231217-AL-002) which was likely associated with the arrival of the O-type CME first seen in STEREO A COR2 imagery at 2023-12-14T17:38Z (see notifications 20231214-AL-007, 20231215-AL-001, and 20231216-AL-002). Simulations indicated that the magnetopause separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma was close to the geosynchronous orbit starting at 2023-12-17T10:54Z (see notifications 20231217-AL-001 and 20231217-AL-003).

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period.

Additionally, there was a solar energetic particle event detected by SOHO and GOES. At SOHO, the flux of one or more of the >15.8 MeV protons channels exceeded 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2023-12-15T15:42Z (see notification 20231215-AL-008). At GOES, the flux of > 10 MeV protons exceeded 10 pfu starting at 2023-12-15T23:45Z (see notifications 20231215-AL-010 and 20231216-AL-001). This solar energetic particle event is likely associated with and influenced by several preceding events which collectively contributed to the observed enhancements. Such events include the observed X2.8, M6.3, and M6.9 flares from Active Region 13514 on 2023-12-14 and 2023-12-15 (see Flares section below for more details), the CMEs first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2023-12-12T00:00Z, 2023-12-13T00:00Z, and 2023-12-15T07:48Z in addition to the the CME first seen in STEREO A COR2 at 2023-12-14T17:38Z (see CMEs table below for more details), and the interplanetary shock detected at L1 by DSCOVR and ACE at 2023-12-17T07:32Z (see notification 20231217-AL-002). The energetic proton flux of 13-100 MeV protons detected at STEREO A was elevated during the reporting period, but remained below the threshold of 10^(-1) pfu/MeV. On 2023-12-17, the particle environment subsided to background levels at all locations and subsequently remained at background levels through the remainder of the reporting period.

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been moderate to high this week due to the solar energetic particle events detected at SOHO and GOES.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2023-12-20T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2023-12-26T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between low and moderate levels during the outlook period. Currently, there are several numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. Active Regions 13519 (S11W58), 13521 (N11E03), and 13529 (S19E27) have produced several C-class flares during the latter part of the reporting period and may continue to exhibit notable flaring activity throughout the outlook period.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. Two coronal hole structures currently centered around S35W25 and N25W07 (as seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO AIA) may become geoeffective during the first half of the outlook period on or around 2023-12-22. The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux was elevated above background levels on 2023-12-20 and such elevated levels may continue to be observed throughout the beginning part of the outlook period.

The shock is caused by CME with ID 2023-12-14T17:38:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20231214-AL-007, 20231215-AL-001, and 20231216-AL-002). Modeled magnetospheric compression observed at 2023-12-17T10:54Z and geomagnetic storm may be possible.

Activity ID: 2023-12-17T07:32:00-IPS-001.

## Summary:

Strong compression of the magnetosphere detected. Simulations carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center indicate that the magnetopause separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma is close to the geosynchronous orbit starting at 2023-12-17T10:54Z.


NASA spacecraft at the geosynchronous orbits may be exposed to solar wind plasma and magnetic field conditions.

Activity ID: 2023-12-17T10:54:00-MPC-001.

## Summary:

BETA PRODUCT. ENSEMBLE PRODUCT IS STILL IN DEVELOPMENT MODE. PLEASE LET US KNOW IF YOU HAVE ANY SUGGESTIONS FOR MODIFICATIONS.  

Ensemble modeling update on CME with ID 2023-12-14T17:38:00-CME-001 (see previous notifications 20231214-AL-007, 20231215-AL-001). Based on analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric ensemble modeling carried out at the Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact STEREO A. For 24 ensemble members (see notes section), simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach:

- STEREO A between about 2023-12-16T14:07Z and 2023-12-17T10:19Z (average arrival 2023-12-16T21:41Z) for 91% of simulations.

Additionally the CME is estimated to reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2023-12-16T15:53Z and 2023-12-17T09:58Z (average arrival 2023-12-16T22:15Z) for 75% of simulations.  The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 79% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 3-6 range (below minor to moderate).

Links to the ensemble details of the modeled event:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-12-16_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA055/20231214_173800_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA055_anim_tim-den.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-12-16_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA055/20231214_173800_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA055_arrival_Earth.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-12-16_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA055/20231214_173800_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA055_Earth_stack.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-12-16_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA055/20231214_173800_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA055_arrival_STA.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-12-16_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA055/20231214_173800_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA055_STA_stack.gif

## Notes:
This CME event (2023-12-14T17:38:00-CME-001) was also predicted to affect OSIRIS-APEX at 2023-12-15T20:40Z and give a glancing blow to Psyche at 2023-12-18T04:00Z (plus minus 7 hours) based on previous heliospheric modeling (see notification 20231214-AL-007).

Ensemble CME modeling at M2M is performed by building sets of initial CME parameters and carrying out separate simulations for each set. This approach allows a mapping of initial CME parameter uncertainties into a statistical characterization of CME arrival times and impact at locations of interest.

Description of links: For each location, the first link shows the WSA-ENLIL+Cone model animation for the median CME input parameters, the second link shows the probabilistic distribution of predicted arrival times histogram, and the third link shows a stack plot of the WSA-ENLIL+Cone modeled magnetic field, velocity, density, and temperature for all ensemble members. For missions near Earth, a histogram of the probabilistic Kp forecast is also provided.

For the full details of the modeled event, please go here:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-12-16_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA055/Detailed_results_20231214_173800_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA055.txt

## Summary:

Solar energetic particle event detected by GOES. The flux of > 10 MeV protons exceeds 10 pfu starting at 2023-12-15T23:45Z.

NASA spacecraft at MEO, GEO and other high-altitude orbits and high-inclination LEO can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2023-12-15T23:45:00-SEP-001.

## Notes: 

Earlier solar energetic particle event was observed by SOHO (see notification 20231215-AL-008), and modeled with MODEL: REleASE:ACE/EPAM 15.8-39.8 MeV (see notification 20231215-AL-007).

This SEP event (2023-12-15T15:42:00-SEP-001) is likely associated with an M6.3 flare from Active Region 13514 (N03W59) with ID 2023-12-15T07:03:00-FLR-001 which peaked at 2023-12-15T07:15Z (see notifications 20231215-AL-002, 20231215-AL-004) and M6.9 flare from Active Region 13514 (N02W66) with ID 2023-12-15T07:23:00-FLR-001 which peaked at 2023-12-15T07:34Z (see notifications 20231215-AL-003, 20231215-AL-005), and CME with ID 2023-12-15T07:48:00-CME-001 (see notification 20231215-AL-009) associated with the aforementioned M6.3 and M6.9 flares. The proton flux at L1 had been already elevated by the X2.8 flare from Active Region 13514 (N05W54) with ID 2023-12-14T16:47:00-FLR-001 which peaked at 2023-12-14T17:02Z (see notifications 20231214-AL-005, 20231214-AL-006), and the associated CME with ID 2023-12-14T17:38:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20231214-AL-007, 20231215-AL-001).

Proton flux at L1 may have been further enhanced by the Interplanetary Shock at L1 with ID 2023-12-15T10:57:00-IPS-001 (see notification 20231215-AL-006) associated with the combined arrival of CME with ID 2023-12-12T00:00:00-CME-001 (see notification 20231213-AL-002) and CME with ID 2023-12-13T00:00:00-CME-001 (see notification 20231213-AL-002).
